Title: Urgent Support Services for Vulnerable Children during Covid-19
Description:
The intention of this contract is to identify vulnerable children and young people who are hidden from view during Covid-19 and provide frontline assistance and support to them. These are children who are not receiving support currently from statutory agencies; and are at risk of harm and/or experiencing adverse impact to their health and wellbeing due to Covid-19.

The contract will focus on supporting children experiencing or at risk of hidden harm. These are vulnerable children who do not meet the threshold for statutory services and do not have an education, health and care plan or child in need or child protection plan and who are not looked after. These children and young people are being adversely impacted by lockdown.

The purpose of the contract is to prevent their needs escalating so that they do not require more significant interventions either now or at a later date. The group of children that will be identified include those who have experienced or are at risk of serious crimes, young people with disabilities and SEND, children in families experiencing domestic abuse and young couples perpetrating domestic abuse, children experiencing mental health difficulties, trafficked children and homeless families and young people.

As a result of Covid-19 measures, there is a specific need to provide additional services to children who either are, or at risk of, experiencing harm because many of the usual mechanisms for identifying risks have been removed or are experiencing other pressures, for example health visitors, police, community hubs, GPs and schools.

In this instance the events that have led to the extreme urgency are the lockdown which has been a key measure in trying to contain Covid-19 and in conjunction with that the closure of schools, to all but a specified minority of children. Whilst that minority has included 'vulnerable children' (as defined in the DfE Guidance: Supporting Vulnerable Children and Young People During the Coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak - actions for educational providers and other partners, updated 15 Mai 2020) not all such children have been in attendance and some children who would not have met the definition of 'vulnerable' at the commencement of the lockdown will have become 'vulnerable' during the lockdown period.

Title: Children's Innovation Partnership
Description:
Leicestershire County Council wishes to procure a Partner to develop a "Children's Innovation Partnership" (CIP) to design and deliver creative service models, which provide cost effective outcome focussed solutions, to meet the aims of the Council's Care Placement Strategy (CPS). The initial priorities will be to offer good quality cost effective residential care to meet the needs of Looked After Children (LAC) with complex behaviours and disabilities and to provide additional capacity to enhance edge of care services. The CPS covers the whole care system from point of entry in Children's Services to leaving care and aims to manage demand and provide the most cost effective placement and support services that deliver the best outcomes for children and young people. The Council wishes to enter into a collaboration agreement with an organisation or lead organisation acting for a consortium that can both design and deliver innovative services that provide improved outcomes for Leicestershire young people on the edge of care through to leaving care including children with Special Educational Needs and Disabilities (SEND). The CIP will include 3 stages:
- design,
- delivery and
- evaluation.
The Council expects the Partner to be able to bring its own financial or in kind contribution to the design stage and to the delivery stage to enhance the Councils statutory requirements in providing services to LAC and children with Send. The Partner must have both the capacity to provide high quality advice and deliver major change in children's services. It is expected that the Partner will have the experience, expertise and quality standards to deliver the majority of services designed by the CIP and therefore must have a proven track record in providing children's services for edge of care, fostering, adoption, permanence and care leavers.
The estimated annual value is 70 400 000 GBP this is based on the 2018/19 budgets for the services covered by the CIP. The estimated total value is 704 000 000 GBP over 10 years. It is not intended that the full budget for each service area will be spent through the CIP. The Council will continue to use existing contracts and frameworks to purchase services. The scope and cost for each service delivered through the CIP will be agreed between the Council and the Partner as part of the design stage and will be within the budget envelope for existing services. The contract duration will be an initial 1 year plus options to extend for a further period or periods up to a maximum of 10 years

Title: Independent Adoption & Special Guardianship Order Support Services
Description:
Kent County Council is seeking to commission a county-wide service regarding Independent Adoption and Special Guardianship Support Services.  The services will be available to those living within the Kent County Council geographical area, or where adoption has taken place through Kent County Council.
The service will consist of four distinct elements:-
Service A: An Independent Support Service to Birth Parents.
This service provides a support and counselling service to birth parents prior to an adoption taking place, where a child is (or children are) in care and looked after by Kent County Council, and for whom adoption has been identified as the plan.
Service B: An Access to Birth Records and Intermediary Services for Adult Adoptees
This service assists adopted persons, either adopted through Kent County Council or who are resident in Kent, and who are aged 18 years or over, to obtain information in relation to their adoption, and to facilitate contact between such persons and their adult birth relatives.
Service C: Access to Information and Intermediary Services for Birth Relatives and those in Prescribed Relationship
This service provides access to non-identifying information regarding the adoption and advice and support to birth relatives and those with a prescribed relationship aged 18 years and over; including access to intermediary services when the adoptee has reached age 18 years or over.
Service D: Contact Services
This service provides contact services, direct and indirect, for children under the age of 18 years who have been adopted, or who are the subject of a Special Guardianship Order and who may have contact with their birth relatives.
Kent County Council is seeking to award one contract covering all the above under this tender process.  It is the Council's intention to award the contract for a period of three years with the potential to extend for a further two years.  
The contract will commence on 1st October 2018.
Please note that these services can only be delivered by an Adoption Support Agency registered with Ofsted.
Further details on service delivery are contained in the Invitation to Tender.
Applications must be submitted via the Kent Business Portal www.kentbusinessportal.org.uk

Title: CS5385 Children' Rights Advocacy Service
Description:
The London Borough of Tower Hamlets (Tower Hamlets) is seeking to commission organisation(s) with the specialist skills and resources to provide a person-centred independent Children's Rights Advocacy Service (CRAS) offering advice and support for all of our Looked After Children and Care Leavers (including those with a disability) to help empower them to reach their potential and uphold their human rights.

The Service consists out of two service lots, Advocacy and Return Home Interviews, for which organisations are encouraged to bid, either for one or both of the service lots.

Service Lot 1:
The Advocacy service lot will offer children and young people (CYP) independent and confidential advice, information and representation, while ensuring CYP have their wishes and feelings heard and views responded to appropriately. 

The Service will:
•	Ensure up to 90 Looked  After Children (LAC) & Care Leavers (including  Children with Disabilities (CWD)) per year will have access to an independent advocacy worker to support their needs and empower them  to help reach their full potential, including making complaints.
•	Conduct up to 25 exit interviews with Care Leavers annually resulting in a report that will be submitted to Tower Hamlets' Through Care Service. 

Service Lot 2:
The Return Home Interview (RHI) service lot will offer independent Return Interviews for Looked After Children who go missing from their placement. Independent return interviews provide an opportunity to speak to the child in confidence to ascertain the factors that led to the child going missing and any risks they may have been exposed to while missing. This will enable Tower Hamlets to implement measures to prevent reoccurrence and to safeguard the child and young person from harm.

Title: Alternative Provision Framework for Children and Young People
Description: Dorset County Council, Bournemouth Borough Council and Borough of Poole are expanding the information we provide on alternative provision by establishing an Alternative Provision Framework. This is a competitive process in order to establish a Framework of value for money, quality assured Providers. The aim is that there will be a variety of Alternative Provision programmes/activities/services supporting children and young people which can be accessed by Bournemouth Borough Council, Dorset County Council, the Borough of Poole and all Schools (including specialist schools and academies). During the planning of this Framework the project group have developed a competitive process for organisations who provide alternative provision services to children and young people, to be added to a quality assured Framework in order that they can deliver their services throughout the county of Dorset, including Bournemouth and Poole. To comply with procurement regulations tenders will be invited for services within the main service categories, which are: * Engagement & Reengagement * Therapeutic * Counselling * Vocational Provision & Employability * Teaching To ensure that a range of Alternative Provision services are made available across the County that can meet the diverse range of needs and circumstances of children and young people, this tender is to establish a Framework of Alternative Provision providers across a range of services. It is our intention that the Framework will run from September 2018 to September 2022. The Framework is designated as a 'Rolling Flexible Framework' which is using the functionality of a Dynamic Purchasing System (DPS) procedure and has been adapted under the Light Touch Regime. As soon as the competitive process closes then the next round will open. This will allow new providers to join the Framework and allow existing providers to change the services that they offer throughout the Framework period. This will ensure that children and young people continue to benefit from new opportunities, from the entry of new providers and have an evolving and wide range of choices/support to meet their needs. The intention is that the Framework will develop and change as required. Existing Framework members will remain on the Framework until it expires, they leave or are removed under the provisions of their individual Framework agreement and they will not need to re-join each year. The Framework will re-open and submissions will be evaluated on a 4-monthly basis. The indicative spend for Dorset County Council is £499,525 per annum. Historically there has been a Dorset County Council contract in place for mentoring valued from £97,900 - £139,008. This indicative spend for Bournemouth Borough Council is £424,869 per annum and the Borough of Poole indicative spend is £197,282 per annum. This Tender is being advertised in the Official Journal of the European Union.

Title: Framework Agreement for the Provision of Short Break Services for Children and Young People with Disabilities in the London Borough of Redbridge
Description:
Framework Agreement for the Provision of Short Break Services for Children and Young People with Disabilities in the London Borough of Redbridge ("the Framework").   

The Framework shall commence on 1st September 2018 and, subject to satisfactory performance, shall continue up to and including 31st August 2021 ("the Framework Period").  At the sole discretion of the Authority the Framework Period may be extended in such period or periods as the Authority deems appropriate up to a maximum of one (1) year, providing a possible total Framework Period to midnight on 31st August 2022.

The Framework is divided into three (3) Lots as follows:- 

Lot 1:  School Holiday Activity, After School Provision and Weekend Provision for Children and Young People Aged 5 to 19 

This will be a Holiday Play Scheme to support disabled children and young people aged between five (5) and nineteen (19) years to access the holiday play scheme every half term. 

The After School Club will be weekly, term-time at the provider's venue for children and young people aged five (5) to nineteen (19) years of age who reside in the Borough with:

•	Disabilities and  special needs; and/or
•	A statement of special and educational needs to include Autistic spectrum disorder, Down-Syndrome, social communication difficulties and general learning difficulties with additional needs.

The Weekend Provision will consist of a recreational transition service for children and young people, giving them the opportunity to socialise with their peers and learn/increase their awareness of challenges that they may face when transitioning from childhood to adulthood. 

Lot 2: Services for Young People Aged 12 to 25 to cover the following: Befriending and Enabling Young People To Access Individual Based Leisure Activities; Transition Support/ Independence Skills for Young People 

This Service will be for young people aged between twelve (12) and twenty-five (25) with moderate to high learning disabilities resident in the Borough.  Each Service User will be offered between eight (8) and ten (10) hours of befriending per month.  The nature of the support shall be Service User led, flexible and vary depending on each individual's circumstances, needs and preferences. Service Users shall be encouraged to meet one another to provide the opportunity for peer friendships to develop within and outside of the Service.  

       	Lot 3:  Counselling and Emotional Support for Parents / Carers with Children and Young People with Disabilities Aged 11 to 24 and their Siblings 

This Service will be for parents/carers with children who are, and young people who are, aged between eleven (11) and twenty-four (24) and have a disability or are the sibling (irrespective of age) of someone with a disability.  Providers will offer a varied emotional health and well-being provision through a wide range of activities including counselling, drop in services and outreach.

Title: Framework Agreement for the Provision of Short Break Services for Children and Young People with Disabilities in the London Borough of Redbridge
Description:
The Council of the London Borough of Redbridge ("the Authority") is seeking Tenders from suitably experienced and qualified organisations for appointment to the Framework Agreement for the Provision of Short Break Services for Children and Young People with Disabilities in the London Borough of Redbridge ("the Framework").   

The Framework shall commence on 1st September 2018 and, subject to satisfactory performance, shall continue up to and including 31st August 2021 ("the Framework Period").  At the sole discretion of the Authority the Framework Period may be extended in such period or periods as the Authority deems appropriate up to a maximum of one (1) year, providing a possible total Framework Period to midnight on 31st August 2022.

The Framework is divided into three (3) Lots as follows:- 

Lot 1:  School Holiday Activity, After School Provision and Weekend Provision for Children and Young People Aged 5 to 19 (In the region of five (5) organisations to be appointed)

This will be a Holiday Play Scheme to support disabled children and young people aged between five (5) and nineteen (19) years to access the holiday play scheme every half term. 

The After School Club will be weekly, term-time at the provider's venue for children and young people aged five (5) to nineteen (19) years of age who reside in the Borough with:

•	Disabilities and  special needs; and/or
•	A statement of special and educational needs to include Autistic spectrum disorder, Down-Syndrome, social communication difficulties and general learning difficulties with additional needs.

The Weekend Provision will consist of a recreational transition service for children and young people, giving them the opportunity to socialise with their peers and learn/increase their awareness of challenges that they may face when transitioning from childhood to adulthood. 

Lot 2: Services for Young People Aged 12 to 25 to cover the following: Befriending and Enabling Young People To Access Individual Based Leisure Activities; Transition Support/ Independence Skills for Young People (In the region of five (5) organisations to be appointed)

This Service will be for young people aged between twelve (12) and twenty-five (25) with moderate to high learning disabilities resident in the Borough.  Each Service User will be offered between eight (8) and ten (10) hours of befriending per month.  The nature of the support shall be Service User led, flexible and vary depending on each individual's circumstances, needs and preferences. Service Users shall be encouraged to meet one another to provide the opportunity for peer friendships to develop within and outside of the Service.

Title: Lancashire Break Time
Description:
"Lancashire Break Time provides opportunities for non-assessed children and young people (CYP) with Special Educational Needs and Disabilities (SEND) aged 4-18 who are unable to access universal services, to participate in social, cultural and/or leisure activities independently of their families, while their unpaid parent(s)/carer(s) receive a break from the caring process. Lancashire County Council believes that as many CYP with SEND as is possible should be able to access and enjoy short break services. The service will be available to service users who live in Lancashire (excluding Blackburn with Darwen and Blackpool). The service is commissioned during school holidays.

The service seeks to improve outcomes for both CYP and their parents and carers. The service advocates that parents and carers are supported in their caring role and those CYP with SEND are supported to engage in life enriching activities and to socialise with their peers in a safe and comfortable environment.

The value of the Framework for the initial period of 12 months is approximately £1,020,000. The Framework may be extended for a further 24 months subject to the conditions set out in the contractual documents.

Title: Lancashire Fostering Agency Placements Framework - RFQ 15180077
Description:
This procurement exercise concerns the provision of foster care services for children and young people (CYP) looked after by Independent Fostering Agencies. The Fostering Agencies offer access to a network of foster carers / families who have been assessed and approved, who can provide a safe environment for CYP to live and develop their lives in a safe environment.

The Authority has a statutory duty to provide foster care to CYP aged between 0-18 years across the County, as well as outside of County also.

The Providers will achieve the following overall outcomes in relation to children placed with their carers:

• Children's welfare is safeguarded and promoted 
• Individual children's outcomes are improved
• Children's basic need for good parenting is met.

Specific outcomes will also be discussed, agreed and recorded within the Service User's Care Plan.

It is intended that call-offs from the framework will be administered by the Council's Access to Resources Team. Referrals will be sent out to service providers who will need to indicate whether they can offer a placement. The final decision on which offers are suitable will be made by the social worker, and if more than one suitable offer is identified the decision will be based upon lowest cost per week.

Title: Hull Headstart Programme
Description:
Hull City Council (the Authority) invites qualified bidders and interested providers to tender for the HeadStart Hull programme being procured under the CPN procedure under the light touch regime .
This service specification sets out the requirements for the HeadStart Hull programme. The programme provides Hull with an opportunity to change the trajectory of some of our most disadvantaged young people, and to impact on their emotional and mental wellbeing and on their academic attainment and school engagement, their risk taking behaviours, long term employability and ultimately their overall life chances.
The service will be divided into the following lots. Providers can bid for 1 or more lots.
Lot 1.	Hull Play Rangers:
To provide a range of high quality play related activities during the school holidays to equip young people aged 10-16 years old and their families with improved communication skills; confidence and self-esteem; build family relationships; and increase peer networks. 
Lot 2.	Young People's Peer Mentoring:
To equip those young people in receipt of mentoring (mentees) with strategies and tools to improve social and personal skills, improve confidence and self-esteem, reduce anxiety, improve peer networks and reduce social isolation both in school and in the community and thus promoting positive emotional health and well-being.
Lot 3.	Hull Parents Peer Mentoring:
To equip those parents in receipt of mentoring (mentees) with strategies and tools to improve emotional well-being and build resilience within families, improve confidence and self-esteem, reduce anxiety, improve family networks and family communication and reduce social isolation through improved parent peer networks in the community and thus promoting positive emotional health and well-being for the family.
Lot 4.	Hull Group Work:
To equip young people and their families with strategies and tools to help improve their social and personal skills, reduce anxiety; improve confidence and self-esteem, enabling self-management socially and emotionally and thus promoting positive emotional health and well-being
Lot 4 will be sub divided into 3 geographical areas relating to the East, West and North of the city, which will be awarded to separate providers.

Under this contract the Supplier will be required to actively contribute to the achievement of social objectives. These include: skills development; employment and training opportunities within the locality of where the contract will be delivered; and other added value initiatives throughout the supply chain to support community programmes promoted by the council. Accordingly contract performance conditions may relate in particular to secondary considerations.
The Authority envisages that the staff working in the current service will transfer to the Service Provider or its subcontractors, under the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (SI 2006/246) (TUPE) along with the Services.

Title: Children & Young People's Emotional Health & Wellbeing Service
Description:
NHS Harrow Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) and Harrow Council are seeking to commission a targeted Children and Young People's Emotional Health & Wellbeing Service for its registered population. 

In March 2015 the government published 'Future in Mind', their strategy for promoting, protecting and improving children and young people's mental health and wellbeing. With the guidance came funding to invest in children and young people's mental health services. In order to access this funding, local authorities and CCGs were tasked with developing local transformation plans, in collaboration with their key stakeholders, which clearly outline how this money will be invested. Harrow CCG and Harrow Council wrote a joint plan with North West London CCG's with 8 priority areas, all with local objectives, which was approved by NHS England in December 2015. 

Priority 5 of our Future in Mind Transformation Plan: Transforming Pathways - A Tier Free System, Harrow local priority is to develop an Integrated Emotional Health and Wellbeing Targeted Service (e.g. CAMHS Tier 2/2.5). This will be an early intervention/prevention provision, identifying and targeted at children and young people with an identified need. This includes Children in Need, children with Special Educational Needs and Disabilities, Children Looked After, children and young people with challenging behaviour, bereavement, life events, school exclusion, OCD, difficulties with eating/sleeping, ADHD and ASD. It will include community outreach and provision in schools. There are an estimated 3695 children and young people (aged 0-18) in Harrow who may be eligible for this provision. 

The service is to be innovative and flexible, offering short to medium term intervention, preventing further escalation of the child/young person's needs and enabling them to be empowered and more resilient. The service will offer a range of therapeutic short to medium term interventions including but not exhaustive of: 

• Direct clinical 1:1 therapy CBT/Psychotherapy/DBT 
• Group counselling 
• Music/art/drama therapy 
• Advice/support to parents/carers/professionals involved with the children and young people

Title: Missing From Home Return Interview Service
Description:
Cumbria County Council has a statutory responsibility to ensure that all children aged up to 18 years who run away or go missing from home or care are offered a return interview when they are found / return home.  The interviews should be carried out within 72 hours of their return.
Independent return interviews provide an opportunity to uncover information that can help protect children from the risk of going missing again, from risks they may have been exposed to while missing or from risk factors in their home.
A disproportionate number of children who go missing are looked after compared with the children?s population as a whole.  Children looked after who go missing are particularly vulnerable and can be at increased risk of exploitation.
Unaccompanied asylum seekers or other migrant children may have been trafficked into the UK.  They may remain under the influence of their traffickers and are therefore at high risk of going missing.
Cumbria County Council provides a return interview service for children who are not allocated to a social worker.

Description:
Northumbria Police have successfully secured funding over the next two years via the Home Office Police Innovation Fund, to protect the most vulnerable in our communities.
This funding will be split amongst a number of current and new projects which are central to the Force’s strategic objectives, as part of this funding the Force is looking to start two new projects relating to domestic abuse.
This opportunity specifically relates to one of the new projects which will be the creation of a programme to tackle domestic abuse perpetrators. 
The Force is looking to appoint a single organisation who can deliver programmes of education for perpetrators of Domestic Abuse across the whole Northumbria Policing area. The programmes will focus on heterosexual male perpetrators who are 18 years old and over, however the Force would be interested in exploring whether services could also be offered to other groups of perpetrators. 
The educational programmes are to reflect the standards which are set and defined by RESPECT and the provider would be expected to work towards gaining RESPECT accreditation.  
The organisations must provide perpetrators easy access to services in each of the six local authority areas in the Northumbria Police area as some perpetrators will not have the means to travel any distances. Gateshead Local Authority
Newcastle Local Authority
Northumberland Local Authority
North Tyneside Local Authority
South Tyneside Local Authority
Sunderland Local Authority

There are already voluntary domestic abuse perpetrator programmes set up in some of the outlined local authority areas across the force.  The successful provider would be expected to work with these existing providers, not in competition with them.  The overall aim is effective service provision across the force area. It is expected that the successful provider will focus service provision in those areas that either don’t have coverage or in the areas where the demand outweighs capacity in those areas that do have coverage.

Title: Young Carers Support Service 2015
Description:
The
				Hull City Council is seeking suitably qualified and experienced
				providers to deliver a Young Carers Support Service. The contract
				will commence 1 June 2015 for a period of 24 months ending 31 May
				2017 with an option for extensions for up to a maximum of 12 months.
				Such extension will be at the discretion of the Council and subject
				to satisfactory performance and monitoring. Young carers are
				children and young people under 18 who provide, or intend to provide
				regular or ongoing care, assistance or emotional support for another
				family member, who is disabled, physically or mentally ill, or has
				problematic substance or alcohol use. They carry out, often on a
				regular basis, significant or substantial caring tasks, taking on a
				level of responsibility that is inappropriate to their age or
				development. Hull City Council is determined to ensure that, as part
				of the Early Help and Priority Families Strategy, young carers are
				given the support they need at the time they need it to enable them
				to manage and balance their caring responsibilities with their right
				to have a childhood. As part of the early help coordination, Hull
				City Council is seeking to establish a contract for a Young Carers
				Support Service to support with the identification of children with
				additional family burdens and to actively work with young carers and
				their families. The aim is to reduce the level of inappropriate
				caring, promote the health and development of young carers and
				develop strong support systems for young people likely to be long
				term carers while not undermining the parent. Under this contract
				the Supplier will be required to actively contribute to the
				achievement of social objectives. These include: skills development;
				employment and training opportunities within the locality of where
				the contract will be delivered; and other added value initiatives
				throughout the supply chain to support community programmes promoted
				by the council. Accordingly contract performance conditions may
				relate in particular to secondary considerations. Suppliers
				should note that TUPE (Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of
				Employment) Regulations 2006) may apply.

Title: LPS CYP - Lancashire Break Time - RFQ 13394498,2
Description:
Lancashire Break Time is a non-statutory service that provides opportunities for non-assessed children and young people (CYP) with Special Educational Needs and Disability (SEND) aged 4-18 who are unable to access universal services, to participate in social, cultural and/or leisure activities independently of their families, while their unpaid parent(s)/carer(s) receive a break from the caring process. Lancashire County Council (LCC) believes that as many CYP with SEND as is possible should be able to access and enjoy short break services. The service will be available to service users who live in Lancashire (excluding Blackburn with Darwen and Blackpool). The service is commissioned during school holidays.

The service seeks to improve outcomes for both CYP and their parents and carers. The service advocates that parents and carers are supported in their caring role and those CYP with SEND are supported to engage in life enriching activities and to socialise with their peers in a safe and comfortable environment.

The value of the Framework for the initial period of 12 months is approximately £1,000,000. Title: Targeted Short Breaks Provision for Children and Young People with a Disability/Complex Needs
Description: A range of providers are required to meet the outcomes of the overarching specification for short breaks. There is however no obligation to award the contract/s following this tender exercise. The aim of the exercise is to award a range of services within the specified financial envelope. The overall contract value is £110,000. The demand in Barnsley for a short break continues to grow at a time when pressure on existing resource is increasing therefore all commissioned services will need to demonstrate best value both at the point of tender and through the lifetime of the contract. It is expected that contract values will vary between services/providers due to differences in outputs, activity and complexity of need/age. Therefore providers must clearly outline in their tender submission the level and type of service they aim to provide and the cost of this service. This should include:  Information in relation to staffing (ratios/experience) which will link to complexity of need in relation to provision provided.  Outputs (numbers of children and duration/frequency of activities)  What it is that will be delivered, the cost of this provision and how the cost will be profiled. All interested organisations must complete the response document provided and be aware that in addition to this document a presentation will also be required. The presentation will be 10 minutes in length with time at the end for questions. The presentation will be delivered to a panel of children and young people who may potentially access your service. The title of the presentation is 'All About My Service'. The panel will score your presentation and this score will be transferred into the tender evaluation process. Criteria for the presentation will be published via YORtender before the closing date for the tender. Our ambition is to make the programme as varied and engaging as possible and the evaluation panel will be willing to consider any suitable proposed activity. The contract/s is being offered for one year only. The contract will be subject to ongoing funding and spending reviews and a period of notice will be built into the contract. The contract start date will be 1 April 2016. During the contracted period services must demonstrate a willingness to develop their services in line with the personalisation agenda.
